pageProps.body:
Differential Equations

cf. Better Call Saul, s06e11, "Breaking Bad"

As it turns out, we can derive close to everything we covered in the Differential Equations course with Linear Algebra - in particular, the solution to second-order ordinary differential equations. For a differential equation of the form

d2xdt2+bdxdt+cx=0,\frac{d^2 x}{dt^2} + b\frac{dx}{dt} + cx = 0,dt2d2x​+bdtdx​+cx=0,

or

x¨+bx˙+cx=0,\ddot{x} + b\dot{x} + cx = 0,x¨+bx˙+cx=0,

the change of variable y=x˙y = \dot{x}y=x˙ (a technique we used in Differential Equations!) yields the linear system of equations in x˙\dot{x}x˙ and y˙\dot{y}y˙​

{x˙=yy˙=−cx−by\begin{cases} \dot{x} = y \\ \dot{y} = -cx - by \end{cases}{x˙=yy˙​=−cx−by​

or, in matrix form,

[01−c−b][xy]=[x˙y˙]\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ -c & -b \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \dot{x} \\ \dot{y} \end{bmatrix}[0−c​1−b​][xy​]=[x˙y˙​​]

This is a special case of the general system of differential equations

Ax=x˙,A\mathbf{x} = \dot{\mathbf{x}},Ax=x˙,

or

[A11A12A21A22][xy]=[x˙y˙]\begin{bmatrix} A_{11} & A_{12} \\ A_{21} & A_{22} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \dot{x} \\ \dot{y} \end{bmatrix}[A11​A21​​A12​A22​​][xy​]=[x˙y˙​​]

As shown, AAA can be transformed into one of three canonical forms through a change of basis with some matrix PPP:

P−1Ax=P−1x˙P−1AP(P−1x)=P−1x˙P−1APz=z˙\begin{aligned} P^{-1}A\mathbf{x} = P^{-1}\mathbf{\dot{x}} \\ P^{-1}AP(P^{-1}\mathbf{x}) = P^{-1}\mathbf{\dot{x}} \\ P^{-1}AP\mathbf{z} = \dot{\mathbf{z}} \end{aligned}P−1Ax=P−1x˙P−1AP(P−1x)=P−1x˙P−1APz=z˙​

where z=P−1x\mathbf{z} = P^{-1}\mathbf{x}z=P−1x, and P−1APP^{-1}APP−1AP is one of three canonical forms:

  1. P−1AP=[λ100λ2]P^{-1}AP = \begin{bmatrix} \lambda_1 & 0\\ 0 & \lambda_2 \end{bmatrix}P−1AP=[λ1​0​0λ2​​]. As such, the system of equations is separated:

    {λ1z1=z1˙λ2z2=z2˙\begin{cases} \lambda_1 z_1 = \dot{z_1} \\ \lambda_2 z_2 = \dot{z_2} \end{cases}{λ1​z1​=z1​˙​λ2​z2​=z2​˙​​

    leading to z1=A1eλ1t,z2=A2eλ2tz_1 = A_1e^{\lambda_1 t}, z_2 = A_2 e^{\lambda_2 t}z1​=A1​eλ1​t,z2​=A2​eλ2​t where A1A_1A1​ and A2A_2A2​ are constants.

  2. P−1AP=[λ00λ]P^{-1}AP = \begin{bmatrix} \lambda & 0\\ 0 & \lambda \end{bmatrix}P−1AP=[λ0​0λ​]. The solution is simply z1=A1eλt,z2=A2eλtz_1 = A_1 e^{\lambda t}, z_2 = A_2 e^{\lambda t}z1​=A1​eλt,z2​=A2​eλt.

  3. P−1AP=[λ10λ]P^{-1} AP = \begin{bmatrix} \lambda & 1\\ 0 & \lambda \end{bmatrix}P−1AP=[λ0​1λ​]. We thus have

    {λ1z1+z2=z1˙λ2z2=z2˙\begin{cases} \lambda_1 z_1 + z_2 = \dot{z_1} \\ \lambda_2 z_2 = \dot{z_2} \end{cases}{λ1​z1​+z2​=z1​˙​λ2​z2​=z2​˙​​

    yielding z2=A2eλ2tz_2 = A_2 e^{\lambda_2 t}z2​=A2​eλ2​t, and substituting into the first equation gives z1=A1eλ1t+A2teλ2tz_1 = A_1e^{\lambda_1 t} + A_2te^{\lambda_2 t}z1​=A1​eλ1​t+A2​teλ2​t.

To obtain solutions for x\mathbf{x}x from z\mathbf{z}z, simply multiply by PPP.
